name: Ad hoc reasoning
definition: Make an exception when an claim has been shown as false, by a new reasoning justifying that exception (in order to let the claim as it was).
frenchExamples: Une licorne rose invisible est proche de moi, c'est prouvé. Mais elle part en présence des sceptiques.

name: Ambiguity fallacy
definition: Using double meanings or ambiguities of language to mislead or misrepresent the truth.

name: Anecdotal fallacy
definition: Using personal experience or an isolated example instead of a valid argument, especially to dismiss statistics.

name: Appeal to emotion
definition: Appealing to emotion in place of a valid argument. By extension, to use emotionally loaded words in order to persuade.

name: Appeal to ignorance
definition: If a claim hasn't been shown as false, it is because it must be a true one.
frenchExamples: Il n'a pas été prouvé qu'une théière n'est pas en orbite autour du Soleil, entre la Terre et Mars, donc c'est le cas.

name: Appeal to nature
definition: Saying that something is natural and is therefore valid, justified.

name: Ad antiquitatem
definition: Using the old age of a claim, in order to say if it is a true one or not.

name: Ad consequentiam
definition: To use the consequence of an argument in order to support or praise an argument. "X cannot be false, or else the consequence Y would be false."

name: Ad hominem
definition: To turn back the claim of someone against himself or herself, in order to disqualify what he or she says.

name: Ad nauseam
alternateName: Being right par reason, Ad infinitum, Argument from repetition
definition: Repeating a claim till it seems true (mecanism of propaganda).

name: Ad novitatem
definition: Using the novelty of a claim, in order to say if it is a true one or not.

name: Ad personam
definition: To attack someone, or his personal traits, that says a claim, rather than the claim itself.

name: Bandwagon effect
definition: Appealing to popularity or the fact that many people do something, as an attempted form of validation.

name: Begging the question
definition: A circular argument in which the conclusion is included in the premises.

name: Broken window fallacy
definition: To assume that when a destruction has occur, it will make the economy work and therefore it's a benefit to society.

name: Burden of proof
definition: Saying that the burden of proof lies not with the person making the claim, but with someone else to disprove.

name: Contextomy
alternateName: Quoting out of context, Quote mining
definition: To quote something out of its surroundings, in a way that distorts its intended meaning.

name: Cum hoc ergo propter hoc
definition: Presuming that because two events are one after the other, there must be a correlation between them. "With that therefore because of that."

name: Division fallacy
definition: Assuming that what's true about one part of something, has to be applied to all, or other, parts of it.

name: Double-barreled question
definition: Asking a question that ought to receive two answers, but that is built in a way that it allows only one answer (yes or no, usually), which will therefore imply a presumption.

name: Epistemic fallacy
definition: To posit an identity between an individual's knowledge towards an object, with the object itself.

name: Fallacy fallacy
definition: Presuming that because a claim has been poorly argued, or a fallacy has been made, that the claim itself must be wrong.

name: False dilemma
definition: To present two alternatives as the only possibilities, while other options actually exists.

name: Genetic fallacy
definition: Presuming that something is true or false, right or wrong, on the basis of where it comes from, or from who it comes from.

name: Ipse dixit
definition: To use the opinion or position of an authority figure (wether it is scentific, educative, religious, military, etc) as an argument, only because of its source ; "He said it himself".

name: Loaded question
definition: To ask a question that contains a presumption built into it, in a way that we cannot answer it without accepting that presumption.

name: Loki's Wager
definition: The unreasonable insistence that a concept cannot be defined, and therefore cannot be discussed.

name: Middle ground
definition: Saying that a compromise, or middle point, between two extremes is the truth.

name: Naturalistic fallacy
definition: Justify what ought to be (prescription) by actually is (description) ; pretend to see a normativity in what exists.

name: Nirvana fallacy
definition: To reject attainable and realistic solutions under the pretext that they are not as good as an ideal solution that is less attainable.

name: No true scotsman
definition: Make a generalisation about something, and then reject the counterexamples under the pretext that they're not true example because they're different from the generalisation.

name: Personal incredulity
definition: Saying that because one finds something difficult to understand that it's therefore not true.

name: Post hoc ergo propter hoc
definition: Presuming that because two events are one after the other, there must be a causality link between them. "Before that therefore because of that."

name: Slippery slope
definition: If we let A happen, then B will necessarily occur, therefore we must prevent A from happening.
frenchExamples: Si l'on abat le droit de propriété privé des moyens de production, alors il y aura nécessairement des millions de morts.

name: Strawman fallacy
definition: Misrepresent an argument to make it easier to attack.

name: The gambler's fallacy
definition: To presume that independant statistical results impacts on each other. For example, if I draw a coin three time, that I get heads each time, the conclusion with that fallacy would be that the chances to get tails are now higher.
frenchExamples: Si je lance 3 fois une pièce en l'air, que j'obtiens trois fois pile, les chances d'avoir face ensuite sont plus élevées.

name: The texas sharpshooter
definition: Cherry-picking data clusters in order to suit an argument, or finding a pattern to fit a presumption (usually a posteriori, in both cases).

name: Trial of intent
definition: To discredit someone's claim by pretending that what he or she says stands on blameworthy intentions (with or without proof).

name: Tu quoque
definition: To avoid to engage with criticism by turning it back to the accuser ; answering criticism by criticism.

name: Two wrongs make a right
definition: Justifying a bad action by the fact that another bad action was commited before ; pretend to fix a wrong by another wrong.
